required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Clavulanic Acid (CLAV) and Cocaine Interaction Safety Study
clinical_study.official_title: Phase 1, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Assessment of Potential Interactions Between Intravenous Cocaine and Clavulanic Acid

brief_summary.textblock: The main purpose of this study is to determine if it is safe to use the study drug, clavulanic acid, in combination with cocaine. In this study, subjects will receive intravenous (i.v.) cocaine and the study drug, clavulanic acid. The safety of clavulanic acid is being studied so future studies can be done to find out if this drug is helpful in treating cocaine dependence. Currently, there is no available medication treatment for cocaine dependence.

primary_outcome.measure: Rates of Occurrence of Adverse Events (AEs) as a Measure of Safety and Tolerability of Clavulanic Acid (CLAV)
primary_outcome.description: Safety and toleration as assessed by the rates of occurrence of adverse events across the three study periods within each subject.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in Cardiovascular Responses as a Measure of Safety and Tolerability of Clavulanic Acid (CLAV)
primary_outcome.description: Cardiovascular responses induced by cocaine infusion will be compared to cardiovascular response measurements before the cocaine infusion to assess change. Cardiovascular changes after infusion given after CLAV (250 mg, 500 mg) will be compared to those without CLAV. We will compare the distribution of Area Under Curve (AUC) summaries of the within-period repeated measures of changes in vital signs (heart rate, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure) across the three-periods within each person.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pharmacokinetic (PK) Parameter of Cocaine and its major metabolite, benzoylecgonine (BE): Maximum Observed Concentration (Cmax)
secondary_outcome.description: PK parameters of cocaine alone will be compared statistically with parameters when both cocaine and clavulanic acid (250 mg, 500 mg) are present. Cmax = Maximum observed concentration

secondary_outcome.measure: PK Parameter of Clavulanic Acid (CLAV): Maximum Observed Concentration (Cmax)
secondary_outcome.description: PK parameters of clavulanic acid alone will be compared statistically at both doses of clavulanic acid (250 mg, 500 mg). Cmax = Maximum observed concentration

secondary_outcome.measure: Pharmacodynamic Effects of Cocaine and Clavulanic Acid
secondary_outcome.description: Pupil Diameter (over time) after cocaine infusion alone (with placebo) will be compared with pupil diameter (over time) after cocaine infusion with clavulanic acid at both doses (250 mg, 500 mg).

arm_group.description: Clavulanic acid OR Placebo to be given in combination with intravenous cocaine; Day #2: Clavulanic Acid 250 mg (low dose); Day #3: Clavulanic Acid 500 mg; Day #4: Placebo; Day #5 Clavulanic Acid 750 mg

Clavulanic acid OR Placebo to be given in combination with intravenous cocaine; Day #2: Clavulanic Acid 250 mg (low dose); Day #3: Placebo; Day #4: Clavulanic Acid 500 mg; Day #5 Clavulanic Acid 750 mg

Clavulanic acid OR Placebo to be given in combination with intravenous cocaine; Day #2: Placebo; Day #3: Clavulanic Acid 250 mg (low dose); Day #4: Clavulanic Acid 500 mg; Day #5 Clavulanic Acid 750 mg

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Meet DSM-5 criteria for cocaine use disorder, moderate to severe.
- Be a non-treatment seeking cocaine user.
- If female and of childbearing potential, must have a negative pregnancy test within 48 hours of beginning the study and be willing to use acceptable contraception or be abstinent for 14 days prior to study, through the entire study and 30 days after study participation.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Be seeking treatment for substance abuse.
(For full inclusion/exclusion criteria or for more information, please contact the site directly.)

overall_official.affiliation: U54 Principal Investigator - University of Pennsylvania
